title: Travel and Accommodation Management
description:
AWG Group (Anglian Water) is undertaking a procurement exercise to assess bidders for the provision of an end-to-end travel and accommodation management system.
Anglian Water is looking to award a contract to one supplier for up to 3 years with option to extend for up to 5 years in any such increments as Anglian Water decide. The supplier will be responsible to deliver the requirements set out in the specification and draft contract documentation provided to Bidders. There is an option to provide additional services of a similar scope. These can include but are not limited to provision of taxi services, conference and meeting facilitation, airport parking. However, as this is an optional scope, the quotes provided for these additional services will not be evaluated as part of the pricing evaluation.

title: Improvement and Journey Management Framework
description:
Yorkshire Water Services Ltd (‘YWS’) is one of the largest Water Utility companies in the UK, with a turnover of GBP 1 billion. YWS provides water and wastewater services to 5.2 million customers. YWS are due to start their new ‘Asset Management Period’ (‘AMP’) and see a culture of sustainable improvement as key to delivering their ambition to continue to provide excellent service whilst keeping bills affordable. YWS are tendering the services that will provide, consultancy/advisory services regarding the development of an internal culture that embraces journey management and continuous improvement.
Lot 1 end to end journey management will require support across the following areas both in a consulting capacity and contracting alongside the core team.Collaborative approach centred around growing capability, supporting and informing the Yorkshire Water approach to enable best-in-class customer experience in an increasingly efficient way for the business.1) Understanding what customers truly value — support in creating an outside-in view of the world by evidencing and synthesising numerous sources of information to create compelling insights to provoke action.Insight— customer opinions (what they say),— customer behaviour (what they do),— FAQs and online search trends (what they search for),— social media and complaints analysis (what they shout about).Customer feedback— gather and analyse ‘voice of the customer’ measures,— identify pain points and gain points,— Benchmark against best in class inside and outside industry,— align customer view across the business.Foresight— understand future customer expectations and opportunities,— challenge the organisation and regulators’ thinking,— inspire stakeholders with what’s possible,— maintain an outside-in view of the industry,— influence organisational strategy.2) Setting clear direction, mobilisation and engagement — making clear connections between business strategy, change programmes and colleague engagementStrategy creation— define CX ambition and goals in line with the organisational strategy,— define, agree and understand the core customer segments/personas,— prioritise key touch points and experiences to apply a dedicated design focus,— identify the cost of inaction as well as the business case for change.Change Implementation— prioritise initiatives and develop light-touch business case for customer and commercials,— robust engagement and handover process with delivery stakeholders,— engage and inform recruitment, training, and coaching initiatives.Organisation engagement— bring the story to life across the business to engage and inspire,— surface and share good news stories and examples of best practise,— gather improvement ideas,— immerse senior colleagues.3) End to end journey management and designSupport a systematic approach to continuously improving end to end journeys against a clear future ‘target state’Journey management— assess and evidence the current reality of end to end journeys on an ongoing basis (emotional, mental and physical effort),— track and monitor improvements, measuring success by impact on customer, colleagues and commercials,— support colleagues to think broader than their own area to galvanise a holistic approach,— focus on the whole customer journey not just the business journey including areas outside direct control,— Governance.Experience design— design and shape end to end journeys collaborating across all key stakeholders and third-party expertise,— develop a robust design process and experience assessment methodology,— surface ideas from within the business and outside perspectives. There are two main needs from an improvement point of view that we will need external support for:(a) working as a deliverer• provide expert consultants who can deliver improvement work where the YW COE do not have the capacity to deliver,• this work will tend to be project based with a defined timeframe and scope. Most likely less complex ‘in team’ or ‘in function’ work,• we would expect this work to be undertaken via our methods/approaches and for any partner to be an extension of the internal YW Team.Examples might be:Process modellers, CI analysts, improvement specialists – people who can deliver improvement interventions as well as do task-oriented activity for process ownership, management and governance.(b) working as a partner to the YW COE• provide expert consultation to work ‘shoulder-to-shoulder’ with the YW COE in delivering their objectives and build capability,• this work could include anything from our portfolio;— the co-delivery of a performance excellence culture within business teams,— improvement project co-delivery (most likely complex, cross functional/business wide),— general advice and coaching to develop our COE,— training co-delivery,— external benchmarking/best practice so that the YW COE can continuously improve their offering.YWS expect this work to be done ‘shoulder-to-shoulder’ with our COE so that a sustainable transfer of skill can take place reducing our reliance on external support for basic improvement delivery.

title: Bus Demand Responsive Transport Network Framework Agreement
description:
The West Midlands Combined Authority (WMCA) is looking to establish an intelligent demand responsive transport (DRT) network framework agreement across the West Midlands area when suitable funding becomes available. A flexible arrangement is required to capture various locations that may come online during the framework which is to be for a period of no longer than 10 years. This will afford the necessary investment in vehicles, staff and technology to take place in order to deliver the various potential DRT schemes.This reflects a step change in the way the WMCA currently procures services within its bus network. An innovative solution is required from operators that needs to be operational towards the end of 2020. The solution needs to be high frequency and demand responsive, capable of integrating with the WMCA's Swift ticketing and operate on-demand plus pre-booked pick up and set down journeys in each area concerned. The framework will consist of two lots.
Lot 1: Technology Platform• rider app and/or API,• dispatch engine operating the system (key requirement),• driver app and/or interface. Lot 2: Operating Platform• fleet of vehicles and trained drivers,• fleet maintenance,• fleet operations and control.

title: Electrician services and installation works within high voltage and low voltage for Sykehuset Østfold (Østfold Hospital)
description: Services primarily include high and low voltage installations (reference NS3420 cf. disciplines W and X) in connection with ongoing and emergency maintenance as well as minor reconstructions works, hereunder:— general electrical works (operation and maintenance),— cabling for automation and control plant installations,— general low voltage works such as data/telephone/antenna/radio/TV and patient alarm systems,— emergency power supply/UPS,— reconstruction/new installations, within both high and low voltage,— alarm systems,— AV systems,— signal installations,— necessary disassembly/reassembly of fixtures.There can also be other types of assignments within the discipline.The size of the assignments within the mentioned disciplines can vary in extent. The work assignments can be for a short or long time. There can be individual assignments or several connected assignments.Østfold Hospital plans to be under way with a number of maintenance measures in St Joseph Hospital, located centrally in Fredrikstad by Autumn 2020. This is planned to be implemented in stages in the period August 2020-December 2022. Electrical and ICT maintenance and assignments will be carried out as call-offs on the contract.There will however also be the delivery of some materials, as in many cases it will be appropriate that the tenderer provides the materials required for the execution of the assignment in question. Even if the procurement includes some materials, it is emphasised that this contract does not give exclusivity for the delivery of such materials and that the contracting authority is not obligated to purchase materials from the service provider.Major works, budgeted to exceed NOK 2 000 000, will be announced in accordance the Public Procurement Regulations and Act.

Even if the procurement includes some materials, it is emphasised that this contract does not give exclusivity for the delivery of such materials and that the contracting authority is not obligated to purchase materials from the service provider.Major works, budgeted to exceed NOK 2 000 000, will be announced in accordance the Public Procurement Regulations and Act.", "tenderPeriod": {"endDate": "2020-05-06T00:00:00+00:00"}, "contractPeriod": {"durationInDays": 732}, "awardCriteriaDetails": "The most economic tender"}, "language": "en", "initiationType": "tender"}], "publisher": {"uid": "https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04962733", "uri": "https://openopps.com", "name": "Open Opps", "scheme": "Companies House"}, "extensions": ["https://raw.githubusercontent.com/open-contracting/ocds_process_title_extension/v1.1.3/extension.json"], "publishedDate": "2020-04-03T09:31:04.325602+00:00", "publicationPolicy": "https://openopps.com/legal/"}

title: A001 — Framework Agreement for the Provision of Legionella and Water Hygiene Management and Control Services
description:
Acivico Ltd wishes to establish a framework agreement for the provision of Legionella and Water Hygiene management and control services. The framework will be available for use by Acivico Ltd in order to support its operations within the West Midlands and Birmingham Area. The framework agreement will last for 4 years. The framework agreement will be split into 2 lots as follows:Lot 1: Legionella and Water Hygiene Risk Assessment, Review, Audit and Consultancy Services;Lot 2: Legionella and Water Hygiene Control and Maintenance Services The framework agreement will be awarded to one supplier for lot 1 and up to 3 suppliers for lot 2. Lot 2 will then be split in to two call-off contracts covering non-housing and housing and awarded in line with the direct call-off/further competition procedures as described in the framework agreement. Suppliers can tender for one or both lots but can only be appointed to one lot.
Legionella and Water Hygiene Risk Assessment, Review, Audit and Consultancy Services. Legionella and Water Hygiene Control and Maintenance Services.
buyer: Birmingham City Council on behalf of Acivico Ltd

title: Arboriculture Works (AHP-322)
description:
This procurement is for the provision of services related to arboriculture maintenance works within the North Somerset and surrounding area such as Bristol, South Gloucestershire, Bath and North East Somerset, Sedgemoor local / unitary authority areas and also in the Swindon area (such as SN1 to SN5, SN25 and SN26 postcodes). This procurement is being tendered under an Open OJEU Procedure. The duration of the contract is for a period of 1 year and 6 months with the option to extend for one further period of 24 months, ending on 29 February 2024. AHG intends to award the contracts on 15 June 2020 to go live on 1 August 2020.
This procurement is for the provision of services related to arboriculture maintenance works within the North Somerset and surrounding area such as Bristol, South Gloucestershire, Bath and North East Somerset, Sedgemoor local/unitary authority areas and also in the Swindon area (such as SN1 to SN5, SN25 and SN26 postcodes). AHG intends to award the contracts on 15 June 2020 to go live on 1 August 2020.

title: Home to School Transport Bus and Coach Services on the Isle of Wight (Mainstream and SEN)
description:
The Isle of Wight Council (‘the Authority’) invites tenders from suitably qualified suppliers (‘Potential Suppliers’) for the provision of home to school transport bus and coach services for both Mainstream and Special Educational Needs (SEN) on the Isle of Wight.This procurement follows the OJEU Open Procedure under the Public Contract Regulations 2015.The Authority has a statutory duty to provide transport assistance between home and school for eligible children following an assessment of each child’s ability to meet the home to school transport criteria.This opportunity is divided into two lots and broken down further to have eight sub-lots as detailed below:Lot 1: Mainstream servicesCoach/bus transport is required to take children to and from school on the Isle of Wight for 190 school days per academic year. The Potential Supplier(s) will provide appropriate vehicles and drivers to deliver the services as per the requirements of the specification. Each mainstream school will be tendered as a separate sub-lot (with the exception of Carisbrooke College and Christ the King College which will be tendered together in the same sub-lot).Each sub-lot contains a different number of routes depending on the Authority’s requirements for each school and the number of children eligible for the services.Sub-lot 1a: Brighstone Church of England Aided Primary School (1 route)Sub-lot 1b: Carisbrooke College and Christ the King College (7 routes)Sub-lot 1c: Medina College (2 routes)Sub-lot 1d: Newchurch Primary School (1 route)Sub-lot 1e: Ryde Academy (1 route)Sub-lot 1f: The Bay Church of England School (2 routes)Sub-lot 1g: The Island Free School (2 routes).Lot 2: Sen servicesCoach/bus transport is required to take children to and from school on the Isle of Wight for 190 school days per academic year. The Potential Supplier will provide appropriate vehicles, equipment, drivers and School Escorts to deliver the services as per the requirements of the specification to meet the needs of the children eligible for the Services. Both the Special Education Needs (SEN) schools will be tendered together in the same sub-lot.Sub-lot 2a: Medina House and St George’s School (7 routes)The term of the contract shall be 1 September 2020 until 31 August 2023 with the option to extend for up to a further period of 3 years, 1 year at a time at the sole discretion of the Authority.The closing date for receipt of tenders is 14.00 on 29 May 2020.

The Potential Supplier(s) will provide appropriate vehicles and drivers to deliver the services as per the requirements of the specification. Each mainstream school will be tendered as a separate sub-lot (with the exception of Carisbrooke College and Christ the King College which will be tendered together in the same sub-lot).Each sub-lot contains a different number of routes depending on the Authority’s requirements for each school and the number of children eligible for the services.Sub-lot 1a: Brighstone Church of England Aided Primary School (1 Route)The term of the contract shall be 1 September 2020 until 31 August 2023 with the option to extend for up to a further period of 3 years, 1 year at a time at the sole discretion of the Authority.The closing date for receipt of tenders is 14.00 on 29 May 2020. title: Contract for the Provision of Operational, Management and Maintenance Services at Dungavel House Immigration Removal Centre
description:
Contract for the provision of operational, management and maintenance services at Dungavel House Immigration Removal Centre.
The authority is responsible, under the Immigration Act 1971 and the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, for detaining and/or enforcing the removal of certain persons (Detainees), being persons detained under the 1971 Act and assigned by the Authority to an Immigration Removal Centre from the United Kingdom. At any one time, approximately 3 400 detainees are held overnight in one of 7 Immigration Removal Centres, 2 residential Short-Term Holding Facilities, a Pre-Departure Accommodation (PDA), prisons and police stations across the United Kingdom. In addition, persons can be detained for shorter periods of time in Short Term Holding Facilities (Rooms) at Reporting Centres, air and sea ports, including locations overseas at the juxtaposed controls in Calais and Coquelles.The authority seeks a commercial partner to provide services at Dungavel House Immigration Removal Centre. Dungavel House has a maximum operating capacity of 200 and accommodates both male and female detainees.The requirement is to provide detention services for occupancy of 125 detainee places at Dungavel House. The maximum capacity of 200 detainee places allows for potential increase in future occupancy requirements. The estimated total contract value, if the increase from 125 to 200 detainees occurs, may rise from GBP 92.33 m to GBP 98.42 m (approx.).The estimated total contract value for the 125 detainee places covers detention services including (without limitation): overall management of the site, security and guarding services; safeguarding and welfare; well-being and cleaning; local escorting and hospital bed watches; recreational, sporting and educational facilities; healthcare provisions, catering and shop services; Religious and welfare facilities; provision of furniture and equipment; facilities management and cleaning services; and landscaping services. the same applies, in the event an increase in detainee places occurs.The length of contract will be 8 years from service commencement, with options to extend, for up to a further 2 years.

title: Corporate Catering Services
description:
The City of London Corporation is seeking a contractor or contractors for the provision of corporate catering services at different sites within the City.The competition will be separated into four lots to reflect the different sites and services required:Lot 1 — Guildhall Staff RestaurantLot 2 — City of London Police staff restaurant at BishopsgateLot 3 — Barbican and Guildhall School of Music and Drama staff restaurantLot 4 — Guildhall School of Music and Drama Kiosks — (for staff/students).Interested bidders may bid for any or all lots.
The City of London Corporation (the City) invites tenders for the provision of workplace catering services at the Guildhall Offices. Provision of staff catering at City of London Police Staff Restaurant — Bishopsgate. Provision of staff catering services at the Barbican and Guildhall School of music and drama. Provision of cafe/kiosk services at the guildhall school of music and drama for use by staff and students.

title: P0628 — Vehicle Scrappage Scheme — Concession
description:
Birmingham City Council is seeking to procure a supplier to implement and manage a Vehicle Scrappage Concession scheme to supply compliant vehicles to eligible grant recipients who meet the requirements of the Worker Vehicle Scrappage Scheme and to dispose of their non-compliant vehicles. The supplier will work with a range of stakeholders including, but not limited to, local car dealerships and local scrap metal dealers. The supplier will be responsible for arranging the auditable destruction of non-compliant vehicles using authorised treatment facilities. The contract is determined to be a concession contract pursuant to the Concession Contracts Regulations 2016 and over the value of the OJEU concession threshold. The duration of the contract will be for 3 years with an option to extend for a further 2 years and will be terminated if grant funding is exhausted before the end of the term.
To implement and manage a Vehicle Scrappage Concession to supply compliant vehicles to eligible grant recipients who meet the requirements of the Worker Vehicle Scrappage Scheme and to dispose of their non-compliant vehicles.

title: Faith Museum
description:
The Auckland Project (TAP) are inviting tenders from multi-disciplinary design teams to deliver the exhibition design for the Faith Museum. The team will provide the following services for the exhibition fit out under one contract:— lead exhibition design including conservation architectural advice;— production of management and maintenance plan (Heritage Fund requirement);— lighting design;— audio-visual (AV) brief development;— audio-visual (AV) hardware consultant;— interactive brief development (mechanical and/or digital);— graphic design;— structural engineering;— services design;— access consultancy;— principal design.The overall budget is GBP 1.8 million for the fit out of the Faith Museum, this includes design fees.
Applicants will be required to complete a standard selectionQuestionnaire available from https://focusconsultants-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/g/personal/elizabeth_farr_focus-consultants_com/EgUCavHQTr1CkdvJm--advsB1Wx9Z0eJvtxwKPWkmAKyLg?e=4FI8RIApplicants will then be shortlisted and 5-7 applicants will be invited to submit a tender.

title: Cambridgeshire Local Authorities — Energy Services and Project Delivery Contract
description:
The contracting authority is seeking a contractor to design and deliver energy efficiency, renewable energy generation and storage projects across all of its asset types (schools, office buildings, rural estate, transport assets, waste assets, housing, etc). This will include building energy efficiency projects, utility scale generation and storage projects and district heating schemes. There is a strong emphasis on both carbon reduction, in order to support progress towards achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050 and revenue generating opportunities. Further detail on scope is provided in the ITT.
The contracting authority is interested in securing a partner to design and deliver energy efficiency, renewable energy generation and storage projects across all of its asset types (schools, office buildings, rural estate, transport assets, waste assets, housing, etc.), irrespective of whether they are within its administrative boundaries,. The service provider may take a consortium approach if it does not have access to all the relevant expertise within its own organisation.The contracting authority has experience of working with Energy Performance Contracting (EPC) since 2014. CCC has invested over GBP 21 million in EPCs to date, with pipeline investments totalling a further GBP 56 million. The ambition for this procurement is greater than ever as CCC and other local authorities have declared Climate Emergencies. CCC has published a climate change and environment strategy including targets for reducing energy consumption of CCC’s building stock, replacing heating in CCC owned and operated buildings with low carbon heating by 2025 and reducing indirect emissions by 50.4 % by 2030.We need to partner with a team of skilled and imaginative engineers and commercial managers that can develop new business models for projects. That team must be supported by senior managers willing to take risk and bring a culture of innovation and change.The successful contractor must provide a full range of engineering design, project management, construction health and safety, energy market commercial and measurement and verification skills with appropriate qualifications and registrations. Tenders will be required to provide CVs for the project team demonstrating the relevant experience and qualifications.The contractor will be required to provide energy performance contracts for the majority of projects called off under the framework i.e. they will be required to guarantee energy savings/generation and back this up with a Parent Company Guarantee or Performance Bond. In addition to reducing its direct carbon emissions Cambridgeshire County Council is committed to reducing its indirect carbon emissions by 50.4 % by 2030 relative to a 2018 baseline. The contractor will be required to demonstrate carbon emissions reductions in their operation and supply chain consistent with this trajectory. Where this is not achieved they will be required to offset emissions to compensate for the shortfall.
buyer: LGSS on behalf of Cambridgeshire County Council

title: Tees Valley Collaborative Trust - Student Transport Services
description:
The trust is seeking a student transport service provision which will allow learners to travel from their home to the Prior Pursglove site and back again daily, on college days only, Monday to Friday, and during term time only.The routes are assigned to Lots as follows: 1. Redcar Wacky Warehouse to PPC;2. Marske/Saltburn to PPC;3. Normanby/Eston to PPC;4. Linthorpe/Acklam/Coulby to PPC.
Current capacity is around 72 passengers on all four routes. Actual capacity requirements will be confirmed when known:— Wacky Warehouse: 8.19-16.29,— Longbeck Station: 8.22-16.26,— New Marske Birkdale: 8.25-16.23,— Yearby Village: 8.32-16.19,— Prior Pursglove College: 8.40-16.10.Above detail is here as a provisional guide at this stage. Current capacity is around 72 passengers on all four routes. Actual capacity requirements will be confirmed when known:— Marske Square: 8.16-16.32,— Saltburn Ox Close: 8.23-16.25,— Saltburn Square: 8.27-16.22,— Saltburn Golf Club: 8:30-16.20,— Prior Pursglove College: 8.40-16.10.Above detail is here as a provisional guide at this stage. Current capacity is around 72 passengers on all four routes. Actual capacity requirements will be confirmed when known:— Normanby Top: 8.07-16.39,— Eston Baths: 8.12-16.37,— South Bank: 8.14-16.34,— Grangetown Magnet: 8.17-16.30,— Whale Hill Shops: 8.21-16.28,— Eston Police Station: 8.23-16.25,— Bankfields Sainsburys: 8.26-16.22,— Norman Conquest: 8.28-16.20,— Prior Pursglove College: 8.40-16.10.Above detail is here as a provisional guide at this stage. Current capacity is around 72 passengers on all four routes. Actual capacity requirements will be confirmed when known:— West Lane Hospital: 7.52-16.58,— Cambridge Road End,— Thornaby Roundel,— Thornaby Town Centre TBC TBC,No pick-ups until Stainton Village, Hemlington Shops, Coulby Newham Parkway Ctr,— Prior Pursglove College: 8.40-16.10.Timings and exact stopping points for lot 4 to be determined with successful supplier.Above detail is here as a provisional guide at this stage.

title: Information Technology — Data Strategies and Delivery
description:
DCMS is seeking to set up a single supplier framework focused on improving and optimising the delivery of the department's IT data strategy.DCMS requires a supplier to undertake the following methodology for each business requirement/statements of work: discovery, design, develop, deliver and support DCMS’ current business processes, reviewing existing data sources and flows and uncovering critical areas for improvement; in particular, applying AI/ML techniques, as well as identifying quick wins for immediate implementation.A supplier is required to develop ‘data strategies’, data governance principles, the solution vision and implement the roadmap for an accredited data platform for various DCMS teams. Although largely understood, the landscape of what the supplier needs to support DCMS with is yet largely to be completely defined, as the requirements of departmental teams are at various stages of development, with some lacking maturity.
DCMS is seeking to set up a single supplier framework via an open procedure as stated in regulation 27 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015).The framework will be focused on improving and optimising the delivery of the department's IT data strategy.DCMS requires a supplier to undertake the following methodology for each business requirement/statements of work: discovery, design, develop, deliver and support DCMS’ current business processes, reviewing existing data sources and flows and uncovering critical areas for improvement; in particular, applying AI/ML techniques, as well as identifying quick wins for immediate implementation.A supplier is required to develop ‘data strategies’, data governance principles, the solution vision and implement the roadmap for an accredited data platform for various DCMS teams. Although largely understood, the landscape of what the supplier needs to support DCMS with is yet largely to be completely defined, as the requirements of departmental teams are at various stages of development.
buyer: Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

title: 20mm KAA Cannon and GAMB01 Mount Spares

title: Offender Risk and Needs Assessment and Case Management Instrument 2020-2024
description:
The Scottish Government has a requirement to place a contract with an external service provider for the provision of an Offender Risk and Needs Assessment and Case Management Instrument 2020-2024. The instrument would be operated by 32 local authority Criminal Justice Social Work (CJSW) departments and within the Scottish Prison Service (SPS) on behalf of the Scottish Government, and would record details of their interactions with clients/offenders across Scotland.
See specification of requirements for full details.

title: ID 2862203 DAERA Drinking Water Inspectorate Private Water Supplies: Delivery of Annual Monitoring Programme to include Scheduling; Provision of Sample Bottles; Collection of Water Samples from Local Councils and Transportation to Laboratory; Analysis and Reporting of Test Results to the Department
description:
The contractor shall coordinate the delivery of the annual monitoring programme for private water supplies registered with the Drinking Water Inspectorate (DWI) under the Private Water Supplies Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2017. This is to include the scheduling, collection, analysis and reporting of analytical results for these drinking water supplies. It should be noted that, under normal circumstances, this contract does not require the contractor to undertake sampling at individual private water supplies; this function is carried out by local environmental health staff at councils across Northern Ireland. The contractor shall schedule these water samples and provide sample bottles; collect the samples from the individual council offices and arrange for their storage and transportation to laboratory; analysis of the samples and subsequent reporting of the analytical results to DWI.
The contractor shall coordinate the delivery of the annual monitoring programme for private water supplies registered with the Drinking Water Inspectorate (DWI) under The Private Water Supplies Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2017. This is to include the scheduling, collection, analysis and reporting of analytical results for these drinking water supplies. It should be noted that, under normal circumstances, this contract does not require the contractor to undertake sampling at individual private water supplies; this function is carried out by local environmental health staff at councils across Northern Ireland. The contractor shall schedule these water samples and provide sample bottles; collect the samples from the individual council offices and arrange for their storage and transportation to laboratory; analysis of the samples and subsequent reporting of the analytical results to DWI.
buyer: Northern Ireland environment Agency Drinking Water Inspectorate

title: Fire Prevention Services
description:
Procurement Assist Ltd is seeking service providers to take part in tendering for a place on a 60 month dynamic purchasing system for fire prevention services. This DPS will primarily serve fire risk assessments and the testing of materials, including external cladding.
Including, but not limited to:• internal inspection of onsite location, wall coverings, ceiling/void spaces, review of fire compartmentation and floor coverings,• external inspection of onsite location, including cladding,• technical visual inspection of the on site sprinkler system,• technical visual inspection of the on site fire alarm system,• preparation and completion of a ‘Client’ Inspection Register,• provision of a schedule of works for the Client (either hard copy or an electronic register).
buyer: Procurement Assist Ltd c/o Integrated Facilities Management Bolton Ltd (iFM Bolton)

title: Recruitment Agency Services
description:
Procurement Assist Ltd is seeking service providers to take part in tendering for a place on a 60-month dynamic purchasing system for recruitment agency services.The services will be split into several different categories — please see the overview document for more information.The DPS will be available for use by iFM Bolton and the whole public sector from across the United Kingdom. The DPS initial application period is 30 days but will remain open until 31 May 2025. Applications from service providers can be made at any time during this period.The DPS is intended to be a fast route to market for clients, with clients not needing any further engagement with OJEU procurement processes.
Including, but not limited to:• a mix of recruitment types from all other categories (or a selection of) from the DPS, or alternative specialism as determined by the client. Including, but not limited to:• different grades of nursing staff, specialist medical staff, portage, technical medical staff, doctors, specialist doctors and general practitioners. Including, but not limited to:• housing officers, contact centre staff, retirement living support staff, rent services staff, ASB specialists and back office support/administration staff. Including, but not limited to:• back office administration staff, technical support staff, IT support staff and facilities management staff. Including, but not limited to:• HR administration staff, HR manager, payroll manager, payroll administration staff, communications officer, communications manager. Including, but not limited to:• mechanical and electrical manager or officer, health and safety manager or officer, trade operatives, asset manager or officer and property service personnel. Including, but not limited to:• finance manager or officer, business analyst, financial accountant, accounts payable administration staff and management accountant. Including, but not limited to:• Chief executive officer, executive director roles, strategic director, operational director, non executive director, board member and chair of the board. Including, but not limited to:• a single supply option that clients can assume full staffing responsibility to the supplier, including KPI monitoring.
buyer: Procurement Assist Ltd c/o Integrated Facilities Management Bolton Ltd (iFM Bolton)

title: Lone Worker and Tracker Services
description:
Procurement Assist Ltd is seeking service providers to take part in tendering for a place on a 60 month dynamic purchasing system for lone worker and tracker systems.The services will be split into 2 categories, as follows:Category 1: Supply of Lone Worker Devices and Monitoring Service;Category 2: Supply of Vehicle Tracking Devices and Monitoring Service.The DPS will be available for use by iFM Bolton and the whole public sector from across the United Kingdom. The DPS initial application period is 30 days but will remain open until 31 May 2025. Applications from service providers can be made at any time during this period.The DPS is intended to be a fast route to market for clients, with clients not needing any further engagement with OJEU procurement processes.
Including, but not limited to:• supply of GPS based (or other) lone worker hardware devices,• supply of GPS based applications for use on mobile devices (panic buttons),• support and monitoring system including roll out of technological system updates. Including, but not limited to:• supply of GPS based (or other) vehicle tracking hardware devices,• supply of GPS based applications for use on mobile devices,• support and monitoring system including roll out of technological system updates and set up of geo-zones (but not limited to).
buyer: Procurement Assist Ltd c/o Integrated Facilities Management Bolton Ltd (iFM Bolton)
streetaddress: Royal Bolton Hospital, Minerva Road, Farnworth

• support and monitoring system including roll out of technological system updates and set up of geo-zones (but not limited to)."}], "items": [{"id": "1", "classification": {"id": "71700000", "scheme": "CPV"}}, {"id": "L0", "relatedLot": "20200428197909_L1", "additionalClassifications": [{"id": "71700000", "scheme": "CPV"}]}, {"id": "L1", "relatedLot": "20200428197909_L2", "additionalClassifications": [{"id": "71700000", "scheme": "CPV"}]}], "title": "Lone Worker and Tracker Services", "documents": [{"id": "tender_url", "url": "http://ted.europa.eu/udl?uri=TED:NOTICE:197909-2020:TEXT:EN:HTML", "format": "text/html", "language": "en", "documentType": "tenderNotice"}], "description": "Procurement Assist Ltd is seeking service providers to take part in tendering for a place on a 60 month dynamic purchasing system for lone worker and tracker systems.The services will be split into 2 categories, as follows:Category 1: Supply of Lone Worker Devices and Monitoring Service;Category 2: Supply of Vehicle Tracking Devices and Monitoring Service.The DPS will be available for use by iFM Bolton and the whole public sector from across the United Kingdom. The DPS initial application period is 30 days but will remain open until 31 May 2025. title: Provision of Insurance and Related Services to Two Rivers Housing
description:
Insurance and related services for property, legal liability and other general (non-life)insurable risks, as required by Two Rivers Housing.
A programme of general insurance and related services for Two Rivers Housing, excluding motor fleet risks (see lot 2) and engineering insurance/inspection (see lot 3). The programme will require Insurance and related services for risks that may include but not be limited to: property damage and business interruption,employers, public, products and property owners liability, business combined/office, money, all risks,computer,contract works, group personal accident, professional indemnity, fidelity guarantee/crime,employment practices liability, cyber and terrorism. Insurance and related services for motor vehicle risks (possibly including motor legal expenses and Occasional business use extensions). Engineering Insurance and an associated programme of inspections for statutory and other items of engineering plant and equipment. The contracting authority may require that LOLER Certification is planned 5 monthly, which will allow the association 1 month to re-book appointments where access has not been gained. In addition, the contracting authority requires that the delivery of LOLER visits is done in line with its 'No access process', this includes evidenced appointments and records of any appointment failures.

title: Insurance for Temple Quarter Enterprise Campus construction
description:
The University is seeking to procure insurances for the construction phase of the University's new campus: the Temple Quarter Enterprise Campus (‘TQEC’) adjacent to Bristol Temple Meads railway station.The following types of insurance are required:— Delay in start up,— Construction All Risks,— Terrorism,— Third Party Liability and Products Liability,— Non-Negligent Liability,— Financial loss.Details relating to each of the risks to be insured are contained in the tender documents.Cover is required from 1 October 2020.
Contractors all risks, delay in start up, third party liability and products liability (Primary Layer), non-negligent liability (Primary Layer). Contractors all risks, delay in start up. Third party liability and products liability (Primary Layer), non-negligent liability (Primary Layer). Excess third party liability and products liability (First Layer), non-negligent liability (First Layer). Excess third party liability and products liability (Second Layer), non-negligent liability (Second Layer). Excess third party liability and products liability (Third Layer), non-negligent liability (Third Layer). Financial loss (Primary Layer). Excess financial loss (First Layer).

title: Provision of Augmented Reality and Trail Interpretation for Davagh Forest (Cookstown), Slievemore (Co. Mayo) and Ballyronan Marina (Magherafelt)
description: Mid Ulster District council and the South West Mayo Development Company seek tenders to commission an organisation to develop augmented reality interpretation along with traditional methods which will enhance a real-world experience and help make the visitors journey more interactive, meaningful and seamless in Davagh Forest, Cookstown, Lough Neagh Myths and Legends and Slievemore Heritage Trail, Achill Island, Co. Mayo.

title: Leicestershire County Council — Superfast Leicestershire Phase 4
description:
The Superfast Leicestershire project is working to extend the availability of Next Generation Access (NGA) broadband across the county of Leicestershire. To this end, Leicestershire County Council has previously invested public funds through three contracts (Phase 1, 2 and 3), to extend the availability of NGA infrastructure in areas where no commercial plans were available from market players as verified through State Aid Public Consultations to almost 97 % of premises in the county.The County Council intends to run a new procurement to secure a telecom provider(s) to deploy Next Generation Access solutions — those capable of achieving a minimum of 30 Mbps download speed — for the remaining areas in scope for NGA deployment. Further information regarding the tender is available in the data room.The procurement will follow an open procedure and with the contract expected to be awarded in Autumn 2020.
East Leicestershire — to secure a telecom provider(s) to deploy Next Generation Access solutions — those capable of achieving a minimum of 30 Mbps download speed for the remaining areas in scope for NGA deployment in an area encompassing the entirety of the districts of Harborough, Melton, Oadby and Wigston, as well as parts of Charnwood and Blaby. It contains 149 854 premises and includes 5 928 target White premises for the purpose of this procurement.

title: Track Systems for Phase One and Phase 2a of the HS2 Project
description:
This procurement relates to track systems and HS2 Ltd intends to award the following contracts:1) Delivery contract for Phase 1 Track — Urban including Birmingham Spur (Lot 1 below);2) Delivery contract for Phase 1 Track — Open Route Central (Lot 2 below);3) Delivery contract for Phase 1 Track — Open Route North (Lot 3 below);4) Framework Agreement for Phase 2a Track delivery and other works (see Lot 4 below).Further information about the scope of works and the lots is set out in the remainder of this contract notice (see also Additional Information VI.3) in relation to related supply contracts) and in the pre-qualification pack (PQP). Expressions of interest are welcomed as set out in this contract notice and the PQP.Note there are restrictions on the number of lots 1 to 3 inclusive that may be awarded to any one tenderer. Economic operators may only express an interest in lot 4 if they are also expressing an interest in one or more of lots 1, 2 and 3. Please see below and the PQP.
The scope of works included within lot 1 includes the following:Design and construction of:— 63 km of resilient cast in-situ slab track,— 21 km of standard pre-cast slab track (a separate supply arrangement),— 38 km of standard cast in-situ slab track or optional pre-cast slab track,— 75 mainline switches and crossings (S&C) units and 18 rail expansion devices (REDs) on a combination of the aforementioned track forms (a separate supply arrangement). The above includes the construction of any Hydraulically Bonded Layer (HBL) or intermediate concrete layers, sleeper blocks or pre-cast elements and the installation of long welded rails (to be supplied free-issue to the Contractor);— 20 No buffer stops — a combination of permanent and temporary units to support a phased entry into service;— 4 km of track spacing infill to provide drainage continuity to drainage systems installed by others;— 36 km of cable containment (troughing), to support the routing of HV and LV cables;— provision of (and subsequent removal of) a temporary railhead at West Ruislip for used for construction purposes,— a permanent maintenance facility at West Ruislip.All of the above figures are approximate.The extent of the lot 1 works includes the installation of all track infrastructure within the urban geographical area, which includes stations, open route, bored tunnels and cut-and-cover tunnels.The lot 1 works include the development of the detailed design for all track infrastructure within the urban geographical area and full integration of this design with the works of others including Main Work Civils and Railway Systems packages. This lot also includes the undertaking of static integration testing of the track system, as well as providing onsite support and facilitation of the dynamic testing phase coordinated by the client.The lot 1 works also include principal contractor duties under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 for the line of route up to and including the permanent boundary, plus any railheads or temporary construction compounds required to support the delivery of the works. This Principal contractor role requires the provision of support to the client to manage the integration and prioritisation of construction activities, as well as the function of administering the Construction Railway Rulebook and managing the movement of engineering trains for itself and others within the working area.Further detailed requirements and responsibilities will be set out in the invitation to tender (ITT). The scope of works included within lot 2 includes the following:Design and construction of:— 159 km of standard pre-cast slab track (a separate supply arrangement);— 22 mainline switches and crossings (S&C) units and 18 Rail expansion devices (REDs) on a combination of the aforementioned track forms (a separate supply arrangement). The above includes the construction of any hydraulically bonded layer (HBL) or intermediate concrete layers, sleeper blocks or pre-cast elements and the installation of long welded rails (to be supplied free-issue to the Contractor);— 4 No buffer stops — a combination of permanent and temporary units to support a phased entry into service;— 81 km of track spacing infill to provide drainage continuity to drainage systems installed by others;— 393 km of cable containment (troughing), to support the routing of HV and LV cables;— provision of (and subsequent removal of) a railhead at Calvert to be used for construction purposes, which is then subsequently converted into an infrastructure maintenance depot (IMD) for the ongoing maintenance of HS2 Ltd's rail-mounted plant fleet.All of the above figures are approximate.The extent of the lot 2 works includes the installation of all track infrastructure within the central geographical area, including through open route, viaducts and cut-and-cover tunnels.The scope of the lot 2 works includes the development of the detailed design for all track infrastructure within the central geographical area and full integration of this design with the works of other railway systems packages. This lot also includes the undertaking of static integration testing of the track system, as well as providing on-site support and facilitation of the dynamic testing phase coordinated by the client.The lot 2 works also include the undertaking of principal contractor duties under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 for the line of route up to and including the permanent boundary, plus any railheads or temporary construction compounds required to support the delivery of the works. This principal contractor role requires the provision of support to the client to manage the integration and prioritisation of construction activities, as well as the function of administering the Construction Railway Rulebook and managing the movement of engineering trains for itself and others within the working area.Final detailed arrangements will be as set out in the invitation to tender (ITT). The scope of works included within lot 3 includes the following:Design and construction of:— 176 km of standard pre-cast slab track (a separate supply arrangement);— 12 km of high-speed ballasted track (design and construction), to link the high-speed infrastructure with the conventional rail national network in the vicinity of Handsacre (north of Birmingham);— 42 mainline switches and crossings (S&C) units and 18 rail expansion devices (REDs) on a combination of the aforementioned track forms (a separate supply arrangement). The above includes the construction of any hydraulically bonded layer (HBL) or intermediate concrete layers, sleeper blocks or pre-cast elements and the installation of long welded rails (to be supplied free-issue to the Contractor);— 93 km of track spacing infill to provide drainage continuity to drainage systems installed by others;— 324 km of cable containment (troughing), to support the routing of HV and LV cables;— provision of (and subsequent removal of) a temporary railhead at Berkswell to be used for construction purposes.All of the above figures are approximate.The extent of the lot 3 works includes the installation of all track infrastructure within the North geographical area, including through open route, viaducts and cut-and-cover tunnels.The scope of the lot 3 works includes the development of the detailed design for all track infrastructure within the North geographical area and full integration of this design with the works of other railway systems packages. This lot also includes the undertaking of static integration testing of the track system, as well as providing onsite support and facilitation of the dynamic testing phase coordinated by the client.The lot 3 works also includes the undertaking of principal contractor duties under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 for the line of route up to and including the permanent boundary, plus any railheads or temporary construction compounds required to support the delivery of the works. This principal contractor role requires the provision of support to the client to manage the integration and prioritisation of construction activities, as well as the function of administering the Construction Railway Rulebook and managing the movement of engineering trains for itself and others within the working area.Final detailed arrangements will be as set out in the invitation to tender (ITT). HS2 Ltd intends to establish a multi-supplier framework agreement (FA) alongside the delivery contracts for lots 1, 2 and 3. The scope of work covered by the FA will be:— the Phase 2a track delivery contract (see below);— the works covered by lots 1, 2 and 3 (or the residual elements of those works) in the event of the termination or other failure of those contracts due to contractor default (see the PQP and procurement docs for further detail);— other parts of the scope of lots 1, 2 and 3 works in the event they are omitted from those contracts for any reasons;— other optional works scope relating to the HS2 Track Systems or wider HS2 Project (See ITT for details). HS2 Ltd intends to appoint the following suppliers to the FA:• the successful tenderers for lots 1, 2 and 3 and, in the event they are different entities,• the second highest scoring tenderer for lots 1,• the second highest scoring tenderer for lot 2, and• the second highest scoring tenderer for lot 3.Economic operators may only express an interest in lot 4 if they do so in addition to expressing an interest in at least one of lots 1, 2 and 3. Economic operators expressing an interest in lots 1, 2 and/or 3 are not obliged to express interest in or ultimately be appointed to the FA. Any call-off contracts under the FA will be awarded following a mini-competition procedure, the rules for which will be set out in the full FA which will form part of the ITT for each lot. Only those parties appointed to the FA will be eligible to participate in such mini-competitions. There is no guaranteed minimum or maximum value of work to be awarded under the FA and HS2 Ltd reserves the right not to launch any mini-competition or award any call-off contracts under the FA, including for the avoidance of doubt, any call-off contract for all or part of the Phase 2a delivery contract. Further information about the operation of the FA appears in the PQP and will be set out in full detail in the ITT. HS2 Ltd reserves the right to provide in the FA for its use by any delivery body or other of its contractors or successor body appointed in relation to Phase 2a of the HS2 Project to call off the Phase 2a delivery contract. HS2 Ltd therefore reserves the right for the Phase 2a delivery contract to be entered into by that delivery body or other contractor or successor body.The Phase 2a delivery contract:HS2 Ltd reserves the right to award one or more call-off contracts for the Phase 2a delivery works.The scope of works included within the Phase 2a delivery contract (which shall be a call-off contract under the FA) includes the following: design and construction of— 119 km of standard pre-cast slab track (a separate supply arrangement);— 5 km of standard cast in-situ slab track or optional pre-cast slab track;— 23 mainline switches and crossings (S&C) units and 23 rail expansion devices (REDs) on a combination of the aforementioned track forms (a separate supply arrangement). The above includes the construction of any hydraulically bonded layer (HBL) or intermediate concrete layers, sleeper blocks or pre-cast elements and the installation of long welded rails (to be supplied free-issue to the Contractor);— 2 No buffer stops — either permanent or temporary units to support a phased entry into service;— 72 km of track spacing infill to provide drainage continuity to systems installed by others;— 314 km of cable containment (troughing), to support the routing of HV and LV cables;— provision of (and subsequent removal of) a railhead at stone to be used for construction purposes, which is then subsequently converted into an Infrastructure maintenance base;— rail served (IMB-R) for the ongoing maintenance of the clients rail-mounted plant fleet.The extent of the Phase 2a delivery contract scope lot 4 works includes the design and installation of all track infrastructure within the Phase 2a geographical area, incl. through open route, viaducts, bored and cut-and-cover tunnels. Principal contractor duties CDM Regs 2015.

title: Hammersmith Academy Cleaning
description:
Currently managed by Enterprise Support Services the Academy is placing their cleaning services to competitive tender and are inviting professional cleaning organisations to bid for the contract with the intention of awarding the contract following due process by Thursday 16 July 2020; with a contract start date of 1 September 2020.

title: EDDRP UK — Invitation to Tender for Branding Services
description:
The Early Disease Detection Research Project UK (EDDRP UK) is a new legal entity that has been created to deliver the Accelerating Detection of Disease (ADD) platform. We have a fantastic opportunity to create a new consumer-facing brand from scratch. The ADD name will need to change and this is a requirement of this tender. We are looking to develop a compelling way of communicating with the UK population, differentiating ourselves from the ‘competition’ and creating a brand experience that encourages people to engage with and relate to, us in the UK. In order to help us do so, there are a number of building blocks that will need to be assembled and specialisms we’ll be looking to bring to the table. In this phase of development, we are looking to appoint a partner agency to create a name and brand identity and deliver the implementation of that identity across a number of communications channels. More information can be found within the tender documents.

title: Revenues and Benefits System
description:
This contract is for the supply and implementation of a revenues and benefits system to allow Oxford City Council to deliver a revenues and benefits service. The service includes the administration of housing benefit, council tax support, business rates, council tax, debt management and discretionary housing payments (DHP). This tender follows the publication of a prior information notice (PIN) issued in November 2019.
This contract is for the supply and implementation of a revenues and benefits system to allow Oxford City Council to deliver a Revenues and Benefits service. The service includes the administration of housing benefit, council tax support, business rates, council tax, debt management and discretionary housing payments (DHP). This tender follows the publication of a prior information notice (PIN) issued in November 2019.

title: Gritting and Snow Clearance Services
description:
Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust requires a gritting and snow clearance service contract for car parks, roadways and walkways at its sites across Dorset and surrounding areas. This tender opportunity is not limited to the Trust and could potentially be used by other Dorset Wide NHS Trusts. However it should be noted that there is no commitment from these Trusts to take up the service.
Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust requires a gritting and snow clearance service contract for car parks, roadways and walkways at its sites across Dorset and surrounding areas. The Trust requires the supplier to obtain reliable weather forecast data in order to implement consistent and defensible decision making arrangements for precautionary salting, providing surety of treatment and protection against litigation. The supplier will be required to provide additional treatments on an ad-hoc basis within 8 hours of instruction from DHC representatives. The supplier will be required to operate a fleet of properly maintained appropriate vehicles and plane, with GPS tracking facilities, full back up and sufficient supplies of salt.

title: NAWC WOLF Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN) System
description:
Description 
 
 The Naval Air Warfare Center Aircraft Division (NAWCAD) Webster Outlying Field (WOLF) Air Traffic Control & Landing Systems (ATC&LS) Division has been tasked to provide support and supplies associated with Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN) equipment and associated components.  This effort is extending the current Basic Ordering Agreement N68335-18-G-0001 for an additional 18 month period.  
 Contract Opportunity Type: Presolicitation (Original)

title: Ground to Air Radio (GATR)
description:
Contract Opportunity Type:  Presolicitation. 
 This synopsis announces that the 7th Contracting Squadron, Dyess AFB, TX, intends to solicit a firm fixed price requirement for the delivery and installation of a Ground to Air Radio (GATR) and IAW the format in FAR Subpart 5.207, as supplemented with additional information included in this notice. 
 The Contractor shall engineer, furnish, install and test (EFI&T) the installation of a shelter and infrastructure to support the new CM-300 series radios or current radios at Dyess AFB near building 9030 as replacements for the existing building at the same location (next to pole 1). New radio equipment (provided by AFFSA section) will be installed following shelter and antenna installation acceptance. The poles will be populated with new antennas, RF cabling, lightning protection, and obstruction lighting if need as specified in the Statement of Work (SOW). All new RF Cables will go directly to shelter by aerial messenger. Installation includes contractor provided generator, automatic transfer switch (ATS) and UPS (unless provided by PCCIE section). The fiber TC Jumbo Switch will be attached to existing fiber optic lines at both the shelter, command post and Air Traffic Control (ATC) Tower user ends (installed by 85th ENI only) and not included in the SOW. The contractor will connect all underground cables to a termination points in shelter for power and trench and lay conduit from a manhole location identified by 7CS for shelter bulkhead network cable installations (Both copper/fiber optic cables).

 This synopsis announces that the 7th Contracting Squadron, Dyess AFB, TX, intends to solicit a firm fixed price requirement for the delivery and installation of a Ground to Air Radio (GATR) and IAW the format in FAR Subpart 5.207, as supplemented with additional information included in this notice. 
 The Contractor shall engineer, furnish, install and test (EFI&T) the installation of a shelter and infrastructure to support the new CM-300 series radios or current radios at Dyess AFB near building 9030 as replacements for the existing building at the same location (next to pole 1). New radio equipment (provided by AFFSA section) will be installed following shelter and antenna installation acceptance. The poles will be populated with new antennas, RF cabling, lightning protection, and obstruction lighting if need as specified in the Statement of Work (SOW). All new RF Cables will go directly to shelter by aerial messenger. Installation includes contractor provided generator, automatic transfer switch (ATS) and UPS (unless provided by PCCIE section). The fiber TC Jumbo Switch will be attached to existing fiber optic lines at both the shelter, command post and Air Traffic Control (ATC) Tower user ends (installed by 85th ENI only) and not included in the SOW. The contractor will connect all underground cables to a termination points in shelter for power and trench and lay conduit from a manhole location identified by 7CS for shelter bulkhead network cable installations (Both copper/fiber optic cables).

title: NATO International Competitive Bidding (ICB): Provide ACCS Software Based Element (ASBE) Voice Communication Equipment (VCE)
description:
The NATO Communications and Information Agency (NCI Agency) intends to issue an Invitation For Bids (IFB) for the provision and the implementation of ACCS Software Based Element (ASBE) Voice Communications Equipment (VCE) at sites in Rinas, Albania; Pleso, Croatia; Zvolen, Slovakia; and Brnik, Slovenia; and integration and remote control of national radio sites in these locations.  
 The VCE at each site will provide the operators with access to G-A-G circuits including HF, VHF, and UHF channels and also voice coordination circuits for tactical data links. G-G circuits provide communication with a wide variety of entities over many different carrier networks. Destinations include radar and other sensor sites; military and civilian Air Traffic Control (ATC) centers; weapons coordination; air defense centers; deployable systems; Command, Control, Communication, and Information (C3I) Centers; and other ACCS entities. Intercom facilities give ASBE operators communication with each other.

title: Provisioning of Services for Annual Flight Inspection
description:
1. Bids are hereby invited for the Provisioning of Flight Inspection Services for the Annual Flight Inspection of all Radio & Visual Navigational Aids operated and maintained by the Airport & Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd AND for the Flight Validation of Flight Procedures for the Colombo FIR. 
 2. Accordingly the scope of this procurement shall be as follows. 2.1. Routine Flight Inspection of all Radio and Visual Navigational Aids at Bandaranaike International Airport 2.2. Routine Flight Inspection of all Radio and Visual Navigational Aids at Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport 2.3. Routine Flight Inspection of all Radio and Visual Navigational Aids at Colombo International Airport Ratmalana 2.4. Carry out Flight Inspection and submission of Flight Inspection Reports and certifications for the inspected facilities. 2.5. Review the Flight Procedures in consultation with company and Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka in order to define the specific Flight Check requirements of each segment for the Purpose of Flight Validation of all the Flight Procedures. 2.6. Carry out Flight Validation and submission of Flight Validation Report for the PBN & other Flight procedures as required by the ICAO Doc 9906 and relevant annexes. 2.7. Flight Inspection of Visual Navigational Aids at Jaffna International Airport for commissioning of PAPIs. This will be an optional item which will be executed based on company’s discretion.

DELIVERY ADDRESS: Public Services and Procurement Canada Esquimalt Graving Dock 825 Admirals Road Victoria, British Columbia V9A 2P1  DELIVERY DATE: While delivery is requested within sixteen (16) weeks from contract award, all the deliverables must be received by 31 March 2021. There is no security requirement associated with this requirement.  Further specifications and information are contained in the solicitation package. Delivery Date: Above-mentioned  The Crown retains the right to negotiate with suppliers on any procurement.  Documents may be submitted in either official language of Canada.

title: LCC-022A Supporting Consultancy (Liverpool Clean Air Plan)
description: Liverpool City Council has been mandated by the UK Government to deliver a Clean Air Plan (CAP) that can be delivered to achieve compliance to the annual mean EU limit value for NO2 in the shortest possible time. The key deliverables and purpose of this opportunity is to source a consultant to provide to Liverpool:(a) Key Deliverable 1: All services and requested supporting material to enable Liverpool to complete the OBC and then all work from Final OBC to full business case submission;(b) Optional Extension 1: Potential to support final design into and during delivery, beyond final design and FBC phase.

title: Employee Engagement Software
description:
Thirteen Housing Group (THG) requires a service supplier to provide a cloud based platform upon which its (approx.) 1 600 employees voices can be captured. This platform will include: - the ability to undertake major (whole organisational survey(s)) or minor (targeted campaigns to specific employee groups) as necessary; - the utilisation of an extensive question bank with ability to create bespoke questions based upon the needs of Thirteen and what it is wanting to ascertain linked to employee experience; - a reporting dashboard that includes sentiment analysis and heatmaps that can be used to compare feedback and identify areas of best practise/improvement; - in addition THG requires the same service supplier to be both proficient and experienced in the area of employee engagement and people science, enabling Thirteen to bring its aspired employee experience to reality.
1.1. Thirteen Housing Group (THG) requires a service supplier to provide a cloud based platform upon which its (approx.) 1 600 employees voices can be captured. This platform will include: -the ability to undertake major (whole organisational survey(s)) or minor (targeted campaigns to specific employee groups) as necessary; - The utilisation of an extensive question bank with ability to create bespoke questions based upon the needs of Thirteen and what it is wanting to ascertain linked to employee experience; - a reporting dashboard that includes sentiment analysis and heat maps that can be used to compare feedback and identify areas of best practise/improvement; - the ability to capture and compare the Employer Net Promoter scoring (eNPS) and data exporting; - ability to connect with all employees including those with limited access to technology through paper surveys/SMS/possible apps; - specific ICT requirements 1.2. In addition THG require the same service supplier to be both proficient and experienced in the area of employee engagement and people science, enabling Thirteen to bring its aspired employee experience to reality. As such THG will require expertise around the following: - a fit for purpose employee engagement and question strategy; -the development of in-house skills through bespoke training and workshops where required; - action and impact planning; - results analysis and feedback sessions as appropriate; - completing advanced statistical analysis to provide insights into statistical trends including identifying factors that predict key people outcomes; - mapping and connecting our existing data with that collected through surveys in order to compare all business intelligence to identify potential trends and provide targeted actions to respond to or leverage the insights gained, etc.

This platform will include: -the ability to undertake major (whole organisational survey(s)) or minor (targeted campaigns to specific employee groups) as necessary; - The utilisation of an extensive question bank with ability to create bespoke questions based upon the needs of Thirteen and what it is wanting to ascertain linked to employee experience; - a reporting dashboard that includes sentiment analysis and heat maps that can be used to compare feedback and identify areas of best practise/improvement; - the ability to capture and compare the Employer Net Promoter scoring (eNPS) and data exporting; - ability to connect with all employees including those with limited access to technology through paper surveys/SMS/possible apps; - specific ICT requirements 1.2. In addition THG require the same service supplier to be both proficient and experienced in the area of employee engagement and people science, enabling Thirteen to bring its aspired employee experience to reality. As such THG will require expertise around the following: - a fit for purpose employee engagement and question strategy; -the development of in-house skills through bespoke training and workshops where required; - action and impact planning; - results analysis and feedback sessions as appropriate; - completing advanced statistical analysis to provide insights into statistical trends including identifying factors that predict key people outcomes; - mapping and connecting our existing data with that collected through surveys in order to compare all business intelligence to identify potential trends and provide targeted actions to respond to or leverage the insights gained, etc.", "tenderPeriod": {"endDate": "2020-05-21T00:00:00+00:00"}, "contractPeriod": {"durationInDays": 1830}, "awardCriteriaDetails": "The most economic tender"}, "language": "en", "planning": {"budget": {"amount": {"amount": 325000.0, "currency": "GBP"}}}, "initiationType": "tender"}], "publisher": {"uid": "https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04962733", "uri": "https://openopps.com", "name": "Open Opps", "scheme": "Companies House"}, "extensions": ["https://raw.githubusercontent.com/open-contracting/ocds_process_title_extension/v1.1.3/extension.json"], "publishedDate": "2020-04-21T09:31:56.193860+00:00", "publicationPolicy": "https://openopps.com/legal/"}

title: Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) for Home to School Transport including Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) and Vulnerable Adults Transport
description:
The STAR Authorities (Trafford, Rochdale, Stockport & Tameside) are looking to establish a dynamic purchasing system for home to school transport including special educational needs and disabilities and vulnerable adults transport. The DPS requires transportation of both children and adults on various regular scheduled and ad hoc journeys in minicabs, minibuses, hackney carriages, tail lift vehicles and multi-purpose vehicles (MPV’s). Clients using the service may be vulnerable and may have learning disabilities, behavioural problems, sensory and/or hearing difficulties, an autistic spectrum condition or another physical disability.

title: RFT for the Provision of a Support and Capacity Building Programme for Irish Civil Society Organisations to Better Access EU Funds
description:
In summary, the services required is the provision of a National Contact Point (NCP) to assist Irish civil society organisations to engage effectively in a range of European programmes.For the purposes of this tender, civil society organisations should be understood to include NGOs, community-based organisations, trade unions, professional associations, social movements and networks, media, academia as well as city and county councils and regional assemblies. The NCP will publicise EU funding opportunities and also provide a support service designed to strengthen the capacity of Irish civil society organisations to better understand, apply for, and to succeed in receiving funding through a variety of EU programmes under the current and next MFF.
In summary, the Services required is the provision of a National Contact Point (NCP) to assist Irish civil society organisations to engage effectively in a range of European programmes.For the purposes of this tender, civil society organisations should be understood to include NGOs, community-based organisations, trade unions, professional associations, social movements and networks, media, academia as well as city and county councils and regional assemblies.It is expected that tenderers will be familiar with sources of existing EU funding and will also acquaint themselves fully with funding opportunities under the current and next MFF. Tenderers will be expected to be able to provide comprehensive advice on EU funding opportunities to the Irish civil society sector as required under the terms of this RFT.The NCP will publicise these EU funding opportunities and also provide a support service designed to strengthen the capacity of Irish civil society organisations to better understand, apply for, and to succeed in receiving funding through a variety of EU programmes under the current and next MFF.
buyer: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade/An Roinn Gnóthaí Eachtracha agus Trádála

title: Provision of an Occupational Health Service — Immunisation Programme for Students at Graduate Medical School University of Limerick
description:
The Graduate Medical School in the University of Limerick,wishes to tender for an occupational health provider to provide a timely, efficient and professional health screen and immunisation service for the students before their clinical placement can commence. The school also requires the occupational health provider to declare students fit (or not) for placement and to advise the head of the school of the medical school or his/her designate on any recommendations arising for students who need special considerations in advance of their placement. Compliance with GDPR as the data controller for the service will also be required.
The Graduate Medical School in the University of Limerick, wishes to tender for an occupational health provider to provide a timely, efficient and professional health screen and immunisation service for the students before their clinical placement can commence. The school also requires the occupational health provider to declare students fit (or not) for placement and to advise the head of the school of the medical school or his/her designate on any recommendations arising for students who need special considerations in advance of their placement. Compliance with GDPR as the data controller for the service will also be required.

title: Full-service Delivery for User Moderation of Content on an Artistic Application (app) in all EU Languages
description:
The procurement as outlined in more detail in the service description (Part B of the tender documents) is for the full-service delivery for user moderation of content on an artistic application (app) in all EU languages, under the artistic direction of Olafur Eliasson Future GmbH (SOEF).
The procurement as outlined in more detail in the service description (Part B of the tender documents) is for the full-service delivery for user moderation of content on an artistic application (app) in all EU languages, under the artistic direction of Olafur Eliasson Future GmbH (SOEF). The moderator shall, on the basis of a framework agreement, be responsible for evaluating flagged content and unpublishing it if necessary, assisted by tech tools in the system's back-end provided by SOEF. Unpublishing removes the content from the app. It will be carried out by the moderator following the community guidelines (CG). The moderator must specify a clear and logical reason from the CGs for each message that is unpublished. In addition to reviewing for CG adherence, the moderator will also be responsible for reviewing general content to collect exemplary messages for artistic purposes. The content should be moderated by a native speaker of the language of each message. The moderator will also be responsible for giving SOEF weekly summary of the moderation activities. All communication with SOEF and the system's back-end will be in English.The value of the present tender is — significantly — below the relevant EU threshold. Accordingly, the present notice has been published voluntarily. The aim is to create the highest possible degree of competition. As a consequence, however, the legal regime for procurement procedures above the EU thresholds does not apply. This applies, in particular, to the possibilities of taking legal action against the procurement procedure or the award decision, respectively. Sections 155 et seq. of the German act against restraints of competition (Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen — GWB) do not apply.

title: Quantity Services for Additional Accommodation at Holy Child N.S., Ballycane, Naas
description:
Quantity services for additional accommodation at Holy Child N.S., Ballycane, NaasHoly Child National School is a Catholic primary school under the patronage of the Diocese of Kildare and Leighlin.Please see attached project brief and schedule of additional accommodation.In summary, the project will comprise:• 2 general classrooms including WCs and storage 80 m2 each = 160 m2,• 2 classroom SEN base 343 m2.• gross floor area (SEN Base and General Classrooms) including circulation, internal walls and partitions = 644 m2, also• other works to include removal of prefabs form site and make good disturbed areas.
